# Assignmnet


::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_bc99fdb29cc18d0abc8a4ed94e877cf1'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Load the file
random_vars <- readRDS("Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
# Create a Data Frame
df1=data.frame(random_vars)
```
:::

1. Find the values of mean, variance and standard deviation

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_2b72136d64830c0a7947701053a474ef'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 1.Mean 
mean(df1$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 33.471
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(df1$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 3510.731
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_b73ae7833dbb93732f67732c1c52db62'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 2. Variance
var(df1$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 340.6078
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
var(df1$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 8625646
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_2d090a798f02c38175885fd0954eb6ae'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 3. Standard deviation
sd(df1$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 18.45556
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(df1$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 2936.945
```
:::
:::


2. The calculated Standard deviations are on vastly different scales. In this case, the large difference in values suggests that the Data Sets corresponding to these standard deviations have very different degrees of variability. Due to this reason it does not make sense to compare them.

3. Calculate Covariance and Correlation


::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_00091c806c91173b904132cd0e8ef7d2'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Covariance
cov(df1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#>               age     income
#> age      340.6078   29700.15
#> income 29700.1468 8625645.84
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_9116b9d1ad59b4dda658a1c9057a047d'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Correlation
cor(df1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#>              age    income
#> age    1.0000000 0.5479432
#> income 0.5479432 1.0000000
```
:::
:::


4. Correlation is generally easier to interpret and compare than covariance especially when dealing with variables on different scales. It provides a standardized measure of the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

5. Compute the Conditional Expected value

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_c0983b4ee22f7c3eca971de8129c4720'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 1
age_18 <- subset(df1, age<=18, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 389.6074
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_a0b272cfbec3f3f142f1d56227665e3b'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 2
age_65 <- subset(df1, age>=65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_65$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 1777.237
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_c8781d9d297b6d5f5909fc53c2e19682'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 3
age_18_65 <- subset(df1, age>=18 & age<65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18_65$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 4685.734
```
:::
:::
